right sided sharp chest pain which was well localized to the right chest worse with breathing and chest movement the patient denied any similarity to previous anginal pain which he noted is more substernal in nature and has not occurred in months the patient was concerned that the pain was cardiac and took two sublingual nitroglycerin without relief and therefore presented to the swebrothers hospital emergency room the patient denied any nausea vomiting diaphoresis shortness of breath abdominal pain melena constipation diarrhea and hemoptysis at the time of admission he notes history of chronic venostasis disease in his lower extremities with bilateral decreased sensation and episodes of neuropathy pain which has not changed recently past medical history significant for coronary artery disease status post three vessel coronary artery bypass graft in non insulin dependent diabetes mellitus times years hypercholesterolemia history of chronic atrial fibrillation peripheral neuropathy in bilateral lower extremities past surgical history three vessel coronary artery bypass graft in left carotid endarterectomy in social history no tobacco history occasional alcohol use the liters heent examination revealed moist mucous membranes without lesions pupils were equal round and reactive to light extraocular muscles were intact neck had no lad or jvd lungs had crackles present with egophony and to change over the right low lateral lung field otherwise clear to auscultation bilaterally heart had an irregular rhythm with regular rate there was ii vi systolic ejection murmur at the right upper sternal border and left lower sternal border there was normal and no or abdomen was soft nontender and nondistended with positive bowel sounds extremities revealed bilateral pitting edema with bilateral changes of chronic venostasis pedal pulses on the left but left foot slightly cool to touch there was no palpable pulse in the right lower extremity but good capillary refill and warm neurological examination revealed cranial nerves ii xii were intact bilaterally motor was intact bilaterally sensory was intact to light touch with decrease in sensory to light touch bilateral lower extremities deep tendon reflexes were bilaterally laboratory data white blood cell count was hematocrit and platelets inr was ptt sodium was potassium chloride bicarbonate bun creatinine and glucose admission ekg was significant for atrial fibrillation at beats per minute with evidence for cold left bundle branch block chest ray was significant for right middle lobe infiltrate consistent with pneumonia hospital course the patient was admitted to the floor for administration of intravenous antibiotics the patient did well overnight in the of the patient had an episode of hypoxia with increased requirement for oxygen and ultimately required face mask for saturation the patient denied any anginal chest pain nausea vomiting or increased shortness of breath stat ekg revealed no changes stat chest ray revealed bilateral pulmonary edema this responded well to iv lasix however the patient continued to require increased amounts of oxygen over the next two days wherein he had further episodes of pulmonary edema requiring iv lasix during this time blood cultures from the time of admission grew out pneumococcus times two which were sensitive to penicillin the patients broad coverage antibiotics were then changed to iv penicillin an echocardiogram obtained on revealed high normal left ventricular size with mild concentric hypertrophy hypokinesis with inferior septum and examination was significant for only rare rhonchi on the right side chest ray of revealed improvement of his right lung pneumonia with persistence of bilateral effusions consistent with his episodes of pulmonary edema fingerstick glucose was reflecting an overall improvement and decreased need for sliding scale insulin the patient was felt to be well and ready for discharge discharge medications old woman with history of graves disease and known cholelithiasis who presented to the leadreid hospital emergency room with hour history of increasing right upper quadrant and right lower quadrant abdominal pain nausea vomiting and fever she had one normal bowel movement on the day of admission she denied pyuria anorexia past medical history graves disease past surgical history none medications on admission included mg po inderal mg po allergies no known drug allergies habits negative smoking history no alcohol intake physical examination on admission revealed an ill appearing female in moderate distress lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally cardiac exam revealed regular rate and rhythm abdomen was soft nondistended right lower quadrant and right upper quadrant tenderness lower greater than upper positive bowel sounds negative murphys sign no shake or peritoneal signs rectal exam revealed normal tone no masses nontender no stool in vault laboratory data on admission included white blood cell count of hematocrit urinalysis revealed red cells procedures exploratory laparotomy appendectomy hospital course the patient was admitted to the floor there she had temperature of and pulse of she continued to experience right upper and right lower quadrant pain lower greater than upper because of known cholelithiasis differential of her right sided abdominal pain included primarily cholecystitis and appendicitis she thus underwent abdominal ultrasound ultrasound revealed right upper quadrant gallbladder with mildly thickened walls gallstones but no common duct dilatation or pericholecystic fluid the right lower quadrant revealed thickened small bowel walls but peristalsis was also identifiable using the ultrasound probe the right lower quadrant was certainly more tender than the right upper quadrant on serial examinations her abdominal pain and tenderness became gradually worse and her temperature continued to remain high spiking to to she was thus brought to the operating room for an exploratory laparotomy paramedian incision was made and appendicitis noted the gallbladder appeared grossly normal she tolerated the procedure well without any complications postoperatively she continued to have high temperature spiking over degrees she also became tachycardic to approximately because she had not been taking her medications for few days preoperatively as well as because she had tremor hyperreflexia fever and tachycardia she was suspected to be thyrotoxic of note she had been in atrial fibrillation one month prior to admission endocrinology consult was obtained and based on their recommendations she was restarted on mg po six hours inderal mg po six hours sski one third of cc po thyroid function tests were sent she gradually defervesced her heart rate diminished and her ambulation was rapidly advanced her wound was noted to be slightly erythematous and she was thus started on velosef disposition medications on discharge included percocet one to two tablets po four hours inderal mg po six hours sski one third cc po mg po velosef mg po times seven days yp rufus poulos hy batch report dictated by marlon kusky

cwbhc am discharge summary unsigned dis admission date report status unsigned discharge date discharge diagnosis left leg wound infection history of present illness ms ploss is year old female with history of diabetes who underwent coronary artery bypass graft on of october for unstable angina with non wave myocardial infection she did well postoperatively and was discharged home in good condition about two weeks after her operation she began to notice some swelling and erythema around her left thigh saphenous vein graft harvest site this increased and she came to the emergency room on of march she denied any fever chills night sweats nausea or vomiting she stated there was small amount of purulent appearing liquid draining from the wound past medical history significant for noninsulin dependent diabetes hypertension coronary artery disease hypercholesterolemia supraventricular tachycardia hiatal hernia osteoarthritis chronic right ear abscess and schizophrenia past surgical history significant for coronary artery bypass grafting with the left internal mammary artery to the left anterior descending artery and saphenous vein grafts to the posterior descending artery and the obtuse marginal artery physical examination temperature with her other vital signs stable her heart rate was regular with regular rhythm and no murmur her heart rate was and her blood pressure was her lungs were clear to auscultation and her sternum was stable her left thigh was erythematous around the wound with large area of induration she had good distal pulses and her left foot was warm the thigh wound had an area of necrotic appearing skin hospital course the staples were removed in this area and large amount of pus was extracted some of this was sent for culture the areas of necrotic skin were debrided and after copious irrigation the wound was packed with sterile gauze soaked in normal saline she was started on vancomycin and gentamicin intravenously and was admitted to the hospital for iv antibiotics and dressing changes her cultures grew out staph aureus which was methacillin resistant but sensative to gentamicin and vancomycin as well as citrobacter which was sensative to gentamicin and vancomycin she remained hemodynamically stable and her white count came down from to stable level of her temperature on the second day after admission was and never rose higher than that the erythema in the area of her wound decreased markedly and she remained pain free the wound began to granulate very well and the lower portion of the wound remained clean and dry while the upper portion required three different debridements over her hospital course after this however the entire wound remained clean and well granulated the dressing changes were continued and the patient was screened for the rehabilitation service to follow up with some strengthening and iv antibiotics and dressing changes follow up culture was obtained after one of the dressing changes which grew out coli which was sensative to cipro ofloxacin citrobacter and enterococci all species have been sensitive to ciprofloxacin the patient was changed from vancomyin and gentamicin to vancomyin iv and ciprofloxacin she will receive total of days of vancomycin and seven days of ciprofloxacin after seven days of gentamicin she was accepted for rehabilitation by woodwa herscotl kuaen region medical center and on of september she was discharged to wellma sgriff hospital in good condition she will continue on an calorie ada diet and her discharge medications include aspirin mg day atenolol mg day librium mg cipro mg days vancomycin mg iv hours days colace mg iron sulfate mg verapamil mg prolixin la mg intramuscularly two weeks she should have dressing changes with wet to dry normal saline gauze to her left thigh wound three times each day as well as wound inspections to make sure that it continues healing as well as it is now she will follow up with dr danser and with her own cardiologist dictated by brandon christiansen zf attending marcos yetter rx vb batch index no ewmv fte cc fax to tiange bradbene memorial

eg am cellulitis signed dis admission date report status signed discharge date service general medical service au alldown memorial principal problem vascular insufficiency other diagnoses diabetes mellitus known vascular disease incontinence recurrent utis hypertension history of present illness this is an year old woman with insulin dependent diabetes coronary artery disease hypertension peripheral vascular disease and ejection fraction of who had left fem peroneal bypass in the past presented with on going left toe pain admitted for left toe vascular insufficiency and cellulitis refractory to treatment for two months the patient reported having her podiatrist clip her nails about two months ago which is when her pain in her foot started she denies any fever chills cough shortness of breath nausea or vomiting at home she was able to ambulate but had significant pain localizing to her left foot and toe she was recently admitted here on july for the same complaint treated with iv levofloxacin and clindamycin for five days and then went home on ten days of dicloxacillin then keflex she comes back on the april with the same pain and infection in her left foot on admission she was afebrile with mild tachycardia and stable blood pressure exam was notable for soft systolic ejection murmur at the base non palpable pulses in her left lower extremity left foot was cool there was swelling over the dorsum of her left foot to the ankle there was superficial ulcer along the medial aspect of the nail bed without purulence she had normal white blood cell count and negative blood cultures taken here past medical history status post cva status post carotid endarterectomy status post fem peroneal bypass in diabetes hypertension inflammatory bowel disease congestive heart failure with an ef of to depression recurrent utis coronary artery disease status post mi non wave mi cataracts stress incontinence medications on admission include lactulose zocor metamucil paxil cozaar neurontin metformin lantus allergies allergies to sulfa mavik and verapamil family history noncontributory social history she lives with her family review of systems as per the history of the present illness admission physical examination vital signs temperature heart rate blood pressure breathing and satting on room air general no acute distress obese heent clear no adenopathy oropharynx clear neck jugular venous distention less than eight centimeters cardiovascular regular rate and rhythm no murmurs rubs or gallops pulmonary clear to auscultation bilaterally abdomen soft non tender non distended no organomegaly obese extremities left foot swollen to the ankle over the dorsum erythema superficial ulceration along the lateral first toenail bed without purulence left foot was cool non palpable pulses in lower extremity neurologic she was intact able to ambulate with some difficulty and pain hospital course the patient was admitted for recurrent vascular insufficiency with superimposed cellulitis likely due to her poor lower extremity perfusion from her peripheral vascular disease an mri was obtained which was concerning for early osteomyelitis and there was concern that her bypass graft in her left leg was not patent she had angiography of the left leg vessels and proceeded to get stenting of the left common iliac and external iliac vessels without complication on may also during her hospitalization she had elevated lfts which were attributed to three gram dose of unasyn that she received in the emergency room the unasyn was changed to iv clindamycin and levo and right upper quadrant ultrasound showed calcified gallbladder wall and no obstruction and her lfts then began to normalize her cardiac status remained stable throughout her admission and she is to be treated with plavix mg for days after the stenting of her iliac vessels picc line was placed on the day of discharge for on going iv antibiotics plan the plan is as follows plavix times days milligrams day iv clindamycin and levofloxacin for another ten days and then switch to flagyl and levofloxacin for an additional four weeks she is to follow up with her pcp dr renato hypolite and vascular surgery clinic as planned please continue checking fingerstick blood sugars and discharge condition stable discharge medications include the following aspirin bacitracin dulcolax clindamycin mg iv eight hours for another ten days colace enema or laxative choice per day for constipation heparin units subcu regular insulin sliding scale lactulose milliliters additional four weeks after that as described above plavix milligrams times days and adalat nifedipine extended release milligrams hold for systolic blood pressure less than lantus units subcu additional plan the patient should have her lfts rechecked in the next week to ensure that they are normalizing dictated by hilton bird wi attending rosendo fargnoli jp fw batch index no ks gaa cc ncmh am aortic stenosis signed dis admission date report status signed discharge date history of present illness the patient is year old gentleman with history of aortic stenosis non insulin dependent diabetes mellitus hypertension and hypercholesterolemia who is preop for cardiac catheterization and aortic valve replacement to be admitted on september he has had an echocardiogram which demonstrates severe aortic stenosis with mitral annular calcification left ventricular hypertrophy and aortic insufficiency also mild tricuspid regurgitation and ejection fraction of past medical history notable for non insulin dependent diabetes mellitus depression hypertension hypercholesterolemia and gout allergies the patient had no known drug allergies medications on admission simvastatin lopressor mg allopurinol mg once day lasix mg three times day captopril potassium replacement multivitamin physical examination his examination is unremarkable he has right carotid bruit and palpable distal pulses chest clear abdomen soft extremity no lower extremity edema hospital course he is seen in consultation by oral medicine for carious teeth since he is preopped for aortic valve replacement and he was cleared by the dentist for this procedure he went to the cardiac catheterization laboratory where he underwent coronary arteriography on november his aortic valve area had been calculated at echocardiogram at cm squared his coronary arteriogram demonstrated lesion of his left anterior descending coronary artery second diagonal and lesion of the right coronary artery he underwent preop carotid ultrasound for the carotid bruit that was noted and he had insignificant carotid disease by doppler he went to the operating room on september where he underwent aortic valve replacement with carpentier edwards bioprosthetic valve and coronary artery bypass grafting times two with saphenous vein graft to the left anterior descending coronary artery and the saphenous vein graft to the posterior descending the intraoperative course was unremarkable his postoperative course was complicated only by mild confusion which has cleared and the patient is alert and oriented he is to be discharged to rehabilitation in good condition on the following medications medications on discharge enteric coated aspirin mg day lithium mg twice day potassium supplementation meq once day pravachol mg once day glyburide mg twice day parnate mg twice day lasix mg once day follow up the patient is to be discharged to the care of dr kim scow cardiovascular division at hany medical center dictated by quinn wachsmuth attending erasmo murphree fw ex batch index no tkgkrz mf cc leon everts aa boyd lovato fallsu

ph am acute renal failure signed dis admission date report status signed discharge date attending spiliakos jody domenic md discharge diagnosis acute renal failure principal discharge diagnosis acute on chronic renal failure brief history of present illness mr deglopper is year old male stage iii chf and extensive past medical history notable for hypertension insulin dependent diabetes and an mi status post cabg in and an unsuccessful catheterization in october who presented following three days of oliguria the patient stated that for the last seven weeks he has been travelling on vocation while he was awake he noted decreased dosages of many of his medicines specifically he reduced his own lasix dose from mg daily to mg he also reduced his lotrel by half from mg mg to mg mg he is also taking humalog units lantus units and humulin units he stated that his glucose levels were well controlled with blood sugars less than the patient reports that while he was away he felt as good as he has ever felt was able to walk greater than longer distances and over all felt much stronger however he states that on thursday night he noticed that instead of urinating as normal of times per night he was found to only urinate times he did not urinate at all on subsequent days and then put out merely point of urine on the day prior to admission he reported that his urinary stream was not the usual strength he did not report dysuria or sensation of being incomplete voiding in addition he noted that his weight usually fluctuated approximately pounds per day but that he had gained approximately pounds since his oliguria presented he notes that his legs are swollen more than usual and he denies chest pain palpitations or shortness or breath medical history the patients medical history is notable for cad status post cabg hypertension hypercholesterolemia chf obstructive sleep apnea insulin dependent diabetes and hiatal hernia allergies the patient has no known drug allergies physical examination upon admission his vital signs were stable with temperature of heart rate of blood pressure and saturating on room air the patient was an obese male he was normocephalic and atraumatic with equal round and reactive pupils his hearing and vision were grossly intact his neck exam was significant for jvd of cm he had no carotid bruits his pulmonary exam was clear to auscultation bilaterally he had normal pmi no right ventricular heave his rate and rhythm were normal he had normal and midsystolic and holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex out of his abdomen was notable for multiple abdominal scars and large abdominal hernia he had positive bowel sounds his abdomen was soft and nontender his extremities were significant for pitting edema to ankles there was no erythema warmth or calf tenderness his neurologic exam was nonfocal his significant labs on admission was hyponatremia sodium of and potassium of creatinine of bun of and glucose of his white cells were his hematocrit was his platelet count was his ua was negative his renal ultrasound showed no hydronephrosis no obstruction and left renal cyst his chest ray showed mild cardiomegaly no effusions or no evidence of pneumonia hospital course by system renal the patients presentation consistent with acute on chronic renal failure which was attributed to low effective arterial blood volume and extensive cardiac history notable for diastolic heart failure in addition to hypertension atherosclerosis most likely contributed to his chronic kidney disease with baseline creatinine in october of he was initially aggressively treated with diuresis with iv furosemide on admission his ace inhibitor was held due to increased renal perfusion his urine output increased over his initial two days of admission and his weight decreased from pounds upon admission to pounds three days later his baseline weight prior to this episode of oliguria was pounds his diurese were held per recommendations of the renal consult team in order to allow for further decrease in his creatinine before he was given them again he continued diurese and began his ace inhibitor therapy prior to discharge cardiovascular during his hospital stay mr sperandio experienced multiple episodes of his typical anginal symptoms as well as more pronounced episode of out of chest pain on hospital day during each event the patient was noted to have no significant ekg changes and his cardiac enzymes were always negative he underwent an echocardiographic exam during this admission which was essentially unchanged from his previous echo on october of his ejection fraction had increased in fact to there was minimal left ventricular hypertrophy he was continued on his regimen of isosorbide mononitrate mg which actually was changed from mg to mg for more continuous coverage he also received his home regimen of aspirin statins plavix and was started on heparin for prophylaxis in addition his magnesium and potassium were repleted as necessary the patient continued his home regimen of lantus humalog and regular insulin by fingersticks and then self administering what he needed to daily regular insulin sliding scale which he self administers levothyroxine sodium mcg daily toprol xl mg humalog sliding scale which he administers to himself daily plavix mg daily lantus units subcu lasix mg daily nitroglycerine sublinguals for chest pain and lotrel mg daily imdur mg daily and lipitor mg daily the patient was discharged to home with followup appointment with dr stoss in weeks trch am dehydration signed dis admission date report status signed discharge date discharge diagnosis ischemic hepatocellular injury alcohol abuse alcoholic cardiomyopathy chief complaint vomiting fever and chills for hours prior to admission and cough history of present illness the patient is year old african american female with history of long standing alcohol abuse with two episodes of alcoholic pancreatitis in the past she is status post floor of the mouth squamous cell carcinoma this was treated with resection and xrt she presents with vomiting hours the patient was in her usual state of health until two days prior to admission when she began to develop upper respiratory infection symptoms with congestion and productive cough the cough was initially productive of white sputum and then later which turned dark in color she denies any blood tinged sputum or rust colored sputum the patients cough and upper respiratory infection symptoms progressed and she began to feel weak on the morning prior to admission the patient awoke from sleep with coughing fit and subsequently vomited she denies any hematemesis at that time she repeatedly had episodes of vomiting over the next hours prior to admission and was unable to drink liquids without vomiting she reports that she took approximately eight to ten tylenol mg tablets prior to admission for her symptoms she became progressively light headed and dizzy especially with standing up she reports subjective fevers although she did not take her temperature and also night sweats she had one episode of diarrhea which was nonbloody and loose her son who is an employee of the hos medical center cafeteria went to visit her and urged her to go to the emergency room in the emergency room the patient was initially triaged to the emergent side of the ew was found to have blood pressure of with pulse of she was transferred to the acute side for management past medical history notable of alcohol pancreatitis in september of and april of squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck as previously noted status post excision in with xrt and hyperbaric oxygen therapy she is also status post multiple dental extractions and one flap revision history of total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo oophorectomy in history of small bowel obstruction status post lysis of adhesions getting an exploratory laparotomy in september allergies she has no known drug allergies medications none family history noncontributory social history one to three cigarettes per day and one half to one pint of brandy each day for long time review of systems as per history of present illness she denies any orthopnea paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea lower extremity edema chest pain or shortness of breath as far as she knows she has no known cardiac history physical examination she was relatively well appearing in no apparent distress her temperature was her blood pressure was her pulse was her respiratory rate was and oxygen saturation was on room air heent pupils equal round and reactive to light and accommodation extraocular muscles intact sclera were muddy without icterus oropharynx was notable for postsurgical changes on the right side and with dry mucous membranes neck notable for no meningismus and jugular venous pressure of approximately cm the lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally heart regular rate and rhythm without murmurs gallops or rubs auscultated and nondisplaced point of maximal intensity abdomen soft with mild left upper quadrant tenderness but no hepatic tenderness the liver edge was nonpalpable there was no spleen tip palpable and bowel sounds were present the extremities were notable for no clubbing cyanosis or edema and were warm and perfuse neurologically she was alert and oriented with intact cranial nerve her strength and sensation were grossly intact in the upper and lower extremities her toes were down going bilaterally and her reflexes were symmetric in the upper and lower extremities rectal examination was guaiac negative data laboratory values upon admission showed electrolytes within normal limits magnesium was white count hematocrit platelets differential polys band lymphs and monos mcv was rdw was alt ast alkaline phosphatase and total bilirubin was with direct fraction of lipase was amylase was her inrs were and her prothrombin time was troponin was chest ray was notable for no infiltrates or evidence of heart failure ekg was notable for sinus tachycardia at with wave of and wave in and wave inversions were noted in and with no chest pain urinalysis was notable for protein trace keto blood leukocyte esterase to whites and squamous cells assessment in the emergency room the patient was acutely treated for presumed sepsis and received dose of ceftriaxone and clindamycin urinalysis results indicated that she had potential urinary tract infection at that time blood cultures were drawn and the patient received iv hydration her ekg was noted to have new wave inversions as compared to previously with an indeterminate troponin she was admitted to medicine for management hospital course the patients hospital course can be summarized as follows cardiovascular the patient has no known cardiac history her cardiac risk factors include cigarette smoking and postmenopausal female age no diabetes mellitus no known hypercholesterolemia no known family history she does however drink heavily and has done so for number of years she has no known cardiotoxic effect secondary to alcohol the wave inversions were noted with an indeterminate troponin the patient was admitted in rule out protocol she ruled out for an myocardial infarction with serial cks which were all below her wave inversions persisted despite resolution of her sinus tachycardia an echocardiogram was obtained which demonstrated dilated left ventricle of cm and an ejection fraction of to with inferoseptal and inferoseptal apical akinesis no ventricular thrombus was noted cardiology consultation service was asked to see the patient to evaluation her in the setting of her new depressed ejection fraction and focal wall motion abnormalities initially she was presumed to have coronary disease which had been clinically silent prior to this she was treated with aspirin lopressor and captopril mg three times day unfortunately the patients blood pressure did not tolerate this antihypotensive regimen and despite efforts to scale it back in dosages the majority of the medicines were held nevertheless the patients heart rate slowed to the she experienced one episode of burning chest pain on the night of admission which was alleved with maalox there were no ekg changes associated with that pain the patient was taken to the cardiac catheterization lab on september the cardiac catheterization was notable for right atrial pressure of right ventricular pressure of pulmonary artery pressure was and the pulmonary capillary wedge pressure was her cardiac output was with an index of the left heart catheterization noted normal coronary arteries without evidence of significant coronary disease her left ventriculogram also noted preserved ejection fraction with no focal wall motion abnormalities dr garret dalrymple of the cardiac consultation service followed the patient in house and felt that the reversal of her wall motion abnormalities could be attributable to the acute effects of alcoholic cardiotoxicity the patient will be discharged on aspirin for primary prevention of coronary disease as her other medications were discontinued the patient was heparinized for her apical wall motion abnormality and low ejection fraction while in house and the heparin was discontinued at the time of catheterization gi the patient presented with an acute elevation of her transaminases the patients transaminases were noted to be less than in september of initially it was felt that these transaminases might reflect alcoholic hepatitis given her significant alcohol history the patient reports that her last drink was on sunday prior to admission she drinks about pint of brandy every day the patients transaminases continued to rise however the diagnosis of acute tylenol toxicity superimposed upon hepatocellular damage from alcoholic hepatitis was also entertained she was empirically started on naphthyl cystine and received approximately two to three doses however that medication was discontinued upon gi consultation the patients transaminases rose to level of approximately ast and alt and the gi service was consulted the patients hepatitic serologies were sent and were notable for positive hepatitis core antigen whereas the rest of her hepatitis serologies including hepatitis hepatitis and hepatitis surface antigen were negative the gi service felt that her hepatocellular injury was most likely attributable to an ischemic shock liver condition she had right upper quadrant ultrasound as well which demonstrated dilatation of the common bile duct to cm with some biliary sludging but no evidence of obstructive lesions given the patients isolated increase in ast and alt and bilirubin without an increase in alkaline phosphatase the diagnosis of ischemic hepatotoxicity was entertained by the gi service on the date of discharge the patients alt had fallen to and her ast had fallen to her total bilirubin had fallen to the patient was asymptomatic from hepatic perspective throughout her hospitalization without any evidence of encephalopathy or asterixis an isolated ammonia level was sent and it was infectious disease the patient had repeat urinalysis that was sent on the morning following admission which was indicative of urinary tract infection urine culture eventually indicated an infection with enterococcus the patient received seven days of ampicillin while in house following her initial first day dosing of ceftriaxone and clindamycin the patients urinary tract infection clear symptomatically she developed yeast infection in her vulvar area secondary to antibiotic therapy and this was treated with topical nystatin the patient was not discharged on antibiotics as she clinically cleared her infection fvn the patient had persistent hypomagnesemia while in house and required significant magnesium repletion the etiology of this hypomagnesemia was unclear however it was attributable to her chronic alcohol use and depletion of total magnesium stores her electrolytes clearly need to be followed closely as an outpatient hematologic the patients inr slightly increased while in house but this is attributable to heparin bolus and supratherapeutic prothrombin time upon discharge the patients inr had normalized she received vitamin mg days as empiric treatment for vitamin depletion secondary to chronic alcoholism as well as the possibility for hepatic synthetic dysfunction hypotension the patients initial presentation for hypotension was attributable to dehydration however it became clear that the patient normally exists with low normal blood pressure of approximately to systolic it was stressed to the patient that she must maintain adequate intake to maintain her circulating blood volume as she seemed to be intolerant to the antihypotensive medicines that were used for cardioprotection random cortisol was drawn and was normal the issue of potential renal insufficiency was most likely excluded the patient will follow up on endocrine and electrolyte issues with her primary doctor discharge medications folic acid mg day nystatin topical cream zantac mg multivitamin one day and aspirin mg day follow up the patient will follow up with dr elroy forcell in mes geert medical center on march dr aamodt was involved in the patients hospitalization and will provide excellent continuity of care as an outpatient dictated by porfirio fussner ai attending stacey etzler oc fi batch index no ghyv ag

vomiting and retching no visual changes from baseline she also reports dysuria and some increased frequency of urination on the morning of admission of note the patient has been admitted in july of this year with similar presentation of nausea and vomiting with increased blood pressures which resolved with treatment for nausea and the resumption of her blood pressure medications medications her medications prior to admission included regular insulin on sliding scale aspirin mg per day plavix mg per day metoprolol mg three times day nifedipine mg four times day losartan mg once day allopurinol mg every other day nexium mg once day ursodiol mg once day and colace twice day the patient also reports taking clonidine mg three times day past medical history remarkable for end stage at the left upper sternal border her abdomen was nontender and nondistended bowel sounds were present no hepatosplenomegaly was noted on exam she did not have rebound or guarding she did not have lower extremity edema distal pulses were present laboratory data pertinent labs on admission include white blood cell count of with polys and hematocrit of her bilirubin was slightly elevated at her amylase was her lipase was her ekg showed sinus rhythm studies included chest ray on which showed stable cardiomegaly with some interval progression in her mild interstitial edema and stable bilateral effusions she had ct of her abdomen and pelvis on which showed small bilateral pleural effusions and small pericardial effusion splenomegaly with spleen measuring cm the liver appeared normal other than for an area of focal fat or perfusion anomaly adjacent to the falciform ligament gallstones were present the stomach and the small bowel were decompressed there were no findings to explain nausea or vomiting and there was no evidence of bowel obstruction the patient also had an mr angio of the abdomen on which was unremarkable splenomegaly cholelithiasis and trace pericardial effusion were noted hospital course by problem this is year old woman with history of end stage renal disease who presented with nausea and vomiting and hypertensive urgency likely secondary to her inability to nausea returned when the reglan was stopped so she was maintained on standing dose of mg reglan before meals an abdominal ct was done and did not find evidence of obstruction or any other findings to explain nausea or vomiting an mr angiogram of the abdomen was also done to evaluate for the possibility of vascular disease but this exam was unremarkable cardiovascular there was concern for demand able to take her medications and her blood pressures were controlled her metoprolol dose was increased to renal the patient was continued on monday wednesday friday hemodialysis while she was in the patient was maintained on an aspart sliding scale and had modest blood glucose levels in the rheumatic the patient had persistent fevers she also had history in her chart of polymyalgia rheumatica hyperlipidemia hypertension coronary artery disease status post right coronary artery stent placement in the left circumflex and the obtuse marginal arteries in total blindness years history of present illness mrs carlo branscomb is year old woman with cardiac risk factors including hypertension insulin dependent diabetes mellitus years elevated cholesterol known coronary artery disease status post mi who presented with hours of chest pain this chest pain began at approximately while the patient was awaiting her ride to the center for the blind where she spends most of her mornings and afternoon the patient began as dull ache substernal in location described as squeezing sensation similar to her past angina but less strong than the angina she had had last week before coming to the er holeo hospital center the patient described this as chest pain she also had shortness of breath diaphoresis and wrist tingling on the left the patient took one sublingual nitro at home with some relief but the pain came back as she walking around her home looking for her hospital identification care she had worsening of the pain with exercise she sat down and her visiting nurse gave her two more sublingual nitroglycerin with some relief of pain and called the ambulance in the ambulance the patient continued to have the pain and she received one more sublingual nitroglycerin and nasal cannula oxygen the pain was gone upon arrival to ahi university of medical center in the emergency department the patient was found to be afebrile with heart rate in the high bp ekg with questionable changes compared to old showing normal sinus rhythm to leftward axis and lvh for her elevated heart rate and blood pressure the patient received mg of iv lopressor and mg of labetalol in the emergency department and was started on heparin allergies no known drug allergies medications zocor mg nph subcu regular insulin subcu captopril mg lopressor mg imdur mg ecasa mg adalat cc mg social history the patient was born in rika hwy scond pringsi vi missouri and immigrated to the na lu clearmode in the patient formerly worked as nurses aide at nac riversredd medical center the patient lives with her son and his wife and their four children the patient has never smoked and does not drink physical examination vital signs heart rate bp oxygen saturation on room air and was afebrile when she arrived on the floor general the patient was alert and in no acute distress and as previously noted the patient is blind heent an atrophic right eye with two palpable recoiled muscles in the upper and lower palpebral margin her left eye is mobile but has clouded pupil area she does not blink to threat chest clear to auscultation bilaterally neck her jugular venous pressure was not elevated heart regular rate and rhythm with audible no murmur rubs or gallops were appreciated abdomen soft mildly obese non tender non distended the patient had audible bowel sounds extremities no clubbing or cyanosis she has trace edema in the lower extremities good pulses bilaterally in her lower extremities and in her upper extremities neuro grossly intact except for her visual exam skin no rashes warm and dry laboratory data initial labs when the patient arrived included normal chem cbc that was normal including white blood cell count hematocrit platelets with polys lymphs and bands on her differential coags pt inr initial ck initial troponin hospital course initial questioning of the patient revealed that she had actually been admitted less than two weeks earlier with similar syndrome of chest pain though as the patient describes worse two weeks previously at that point the patient had had modified bruce protocol with duration of the test minutes seconds with of heart rate achieved the patient had stopped secondary to chest pain and had had st wave segment abnormalities with mm st segment depressions in inferior leads and angina the test was interpreted as being highly predictive of significant coronary disease however at that time the patient refused catheterization and decided on medical management for this anginal pain however with the return of this pain and her return admission to the hospital the patient made the decision that she would be catheterized and she was placed on this schedule other initial interventions other than what was done in the emergency room which included maximizing blood pressure and heart rate management with lopressor the patient was continued on her daily aspirin and zocor the patient was ruled out for mi the patients cholesterol and lipids were checked and an initial echocardiogram was also obtained on the patient that echo done on in the morning revealed overall normal left ventricular size with preserved systolic function an estimated ejection fraction of and hypokinesis of inferior posterior wall and septum the mitral valve was minimally thickened with minimal mitral regurgitation there was no significant aortic or tricuspid valve regurgitation or dysfunction there was normal right ventricular size and function there was no evidence of pericardial effusion the left ventricle was thought to be moderate to severely hypertrophied however the inferior posterior walls were less hypertrophied than other areas the patient had one episode of chest pain over the weekend as her cath was planned for monday morning this chest pain occurred on again of elevated blood pressure it was relieved by increasing her iv tng drip to mg iv lopressor and three sublingual nitroglycerins the patient had no ekg changes and had no other chest pain over the weekend the patient was continued on heparin iv tng aspirin and captopril over the week her lopressor was increased to mg for better beta blockade the patient also had her dose of nph adjusted to half her regular dose as she was having low blood sugars the patients catheterization ultimately was findings included clean left main coronary artery lad with luminal irregularities small vessel in general and with about stenosis also small vessel and circumflex with about mid stenosis the rca where her past stents had been placed was completely occluded which was ballooned and brief examination of the abdominal aorta for renal artery stenosis revealed no evidence of renal artery stenosis thus no stents were placed but the patients old stents were ballooned open with good achieved flow and residual after ballooning the patient continued to do well the day post cath and ultimately was sent home the following morning with follow up with her cardiologist dr zinkl discharge medications ecasa mg captopril mg nph subcu regular subcu nitroglycerin sl tab minutes as needed for chest pain zocor mg imdur mg adalat cc mg lopressor mg discharge follow up the medical problems including cad chf and cancer with head and neck presenting with change in mental status possibly due to his methadone dosage versus infectious etiology namely pneumonia hyperglycemia at admission may have been contributory pulmonary blood cultures were negative for growth he was initially placed on cefotaxime and flagyl and was changed to meds per tube meds flagyl and cefpodoxime he was continued on his albuterol nebulizer atrovent and repeat chest ray after intravenous fluids revealed slight improvement he from the respiratory standpoint gradually improved with marked am discharge summary signed dis admission date report status signed discharge date principal diagnosis dyspnea on exertion known coronary artery disease history of present illness the patient is year old gentleman with chest pain syndrome and known coronary artery disease admitted with increasing exertional dyspnea thought to be his anginal equivalent he was admitted for medical management and possible laser angioplasty of an occluded left circumflex coronary artery in january the patient was admitted with an acute chest pain syndrome cardiac catheterization at that time demonstrated occlusion of the left circumflex artery which was heavily calcified and not amenable to balloon angioplasty the patient underwent an exercise tolerance test on may where he exercised six minutes and stopped secondary to fatigue the patient had no chest discomfort or ecg changes during the exercise test he was discharged home on medical regimen including enteric coated aspirin hydrochlorothiazide once day metoprolol mg nitro patch mg per hour and sublingual nitroglycerin the patient also continued on verapamil sr mg for his high blood pressure at home the patient reports that he has not been exercising as frequently as he used to and his exercise regimen usually consisted of minutes on ski machine three times week he continues to get some exertional dyspnea and also has episodes of chest pain usually after meal while he is lying in bed this probably represents reflux disease due to the increasing frequency of his dyspneic episodes with exertion the patient contacted his primary cardiologist jared stockel and it was felt that he probably needed to be admitted for better medical management and to have an attempted laser angioplasty of his occluded left circumflex artery admission medications enteric coated aspirin one tablet day hydrochlorothiazide mg day verapamil sr dur meq day lopressor mg and nitro patch mg times two patches times two hours day physical examination the patient is an elderly gentleman in no apparent distress his heart rate was and regular blood pressure was heent examination was unremarkable his lungs were clear cardiovascular examination was significant for an normal no murmurs his abdomen was benign his extremities had no clubbing cyanosis or edema laboratory data his ecg showed sinus bradycardia at with left anterior vesicular block and right bundle branch block borderline left atrial enlargement chest ray was clear sma was normal other than slightly high creatinine at and low potassium of he had normal cbc and normal pt ptt assessment in summary this is year old gentleman with known coronary artery disease known occlusion of the left circumflex with an exercise tolerance test one year ago without evidence for ischemia he presents with chest pain shortness of breath syndrome etiology of which is unclear hospital course he was admitted to the cardiology ny team where he underwent exercise tolerance test on april during which he went minutes and seconds he stopped secondary to dyspnea on exertion and leg fatigue with no chest pain he had nonspecific changes in his ecg and his mibi images revealed inferolateral ischemia on july he underwent cardiac catheterization with laser assisted ptca of his left circumflex lesion which he tolerated well his post catheterization course was slightly complicated by increased bleeding from the groin site as well as the possible development of hematoma versus pseudoaneurysm as bruit was heard in the right groin this was evaluated with vascular ultrasound which showed no hematoma and no pseudoaneurysm he was observed overnight and was discharged on in stable condition his blood pressure medications were manipulated for better control of his significant hypertension as well as for increased outpatient compliance during his hospitalization urine cultures were sent which grew alpha hemolytic streptococcus this was treated with ampicillin initially and he will be sent home on pen vk also of note during this admission hemoglobin was sent which was slightly elevated at he started on glyburide mg day however the patient felt that he did not need to take this and refused it his medical team felt that it was more important for him to be compliant with his hypertension and cardiac medications at this juncture and the issue of restarting glyburide will be brought up in the outpatient setting by dr boncella he is discharged today august with vna services to monitor medicine compliance and measure blood pressures as well as for home safety evaluation discharge medications enteric coated aspirin mg day atenolol mg day hydrochlorothiazide mg day lisinopril mg day adalat cc mg day nitroglycerin one tablet sublingually minutes times three chest pain prilosec mg day simvastatin mg and pen vk mg times five days dictated by jamey quentin gropper kv attending sammie lobaugh ly ym batch index no bdiyymd

evenings the patients hematocrit had dropped to on postoperative operative day and he was transfused one unit of packed red blood cells with an appropriate hematocrit bumped to on postoperative days through the patient continued his slow steady progress the neurology team who had visited him after surgery after his mental status changes recommended holding his sinemet and only to restart if his parkinson symptoms reoccur otherwise the patient experienced some hypertension and his blood pressure medications were titrated accordingly the patient remained in sinus rhythm by postoperative day his blood pressure was stable he was oxygenating well on room air and was ambulating comfortably in the halls he had sitter accompany him in his room for impulsivity however this became unnecessary after postoperative day pa and lateral chest ray looked clear with no infiltrates and no pneumothorax he had returned to his baseline mental status and he was deemed ready for discharge to the rehabilitation facility which is owned by his daughter on the day of discharge the patients vital signs were temperature degrees heart rate in sinus rhythm blood pressure saturation on room air respiratory rate the patient was still several kilograms above his preoperative weight urinalysis had suggested low level infection and his urine culture was growing proteus cfus and he was started on wmc am discharge summary signed dis admission date report status signed discharge date date of discharge attending noe demetrius mandella md admitting diagnosis shortness of breath discharge diagnoses pulmonary fibrosis pulmonary hypertension diverticulitis acute renal failure gout hypertension high cholesterol diabetes mellitus brief history of present illness the patient is year old female with past medical history of significant obesity diabetes hypertension hypercholesterolemia heart failure pulmonary fibrosis on home who presented with shortness of breath and left jaw pain on she had been in her usual state of health until approximately on the day of admission when at that time she suddenly became short of breath she reports that she then sat down in her wheelchair and passed out however it is unclear if the patient actually lost consciousness the patient also developed jaw pain radiating to her back while emts were present and also complained of tug in her chest the pain was unrelieved by nitroglycerin oxygen it was constant in nature at the time of her arrival in the emergency room the patient was hemodynamically stable with an sat of on room air she was given sublingual nitrate with no effect because of her history of coronary artery disease she was tried on heparin and aspirin past medical history pulmonary fibrosis on home reported history of an anterolateral mi diabetes hypertension high cholesterol medications on admission insulin units units atenolol zocor zoloft lasix neurontin aspirin and multivitamin allergies penicillin physical examination on admission temperature was pulse was blood pressure was and sat was to on liters she was moderately obese woman in no acute distress her lung are notable for crackles at the bases her cardiac exam was notable for distant heart sounds with normal she had no pedal edema in her extremities laboratory data on admission were notable for bun and creatinine of and normal lfts the patients hematocrit was her dimer was her ekg showed normal sinus at low voltages poor wave progression impression at the time of admission the patient was year old female with morbid obesity and chronic episodes of shortness of breath this time accompanied by jaw pain and with history of coronary artery disease and multiple risk factors concerning for acute coronary syndrome the patient was initially treated for possible ischemic event diagnosis of pe results were considered however the patient was not tachycardic she did not have any chest pain or new requirements and had had several workups for pulmonary embolism during prior hospitalization with similar systems so therefore this was thought to be less likely hospital course by system cardiac in terms of ischemia the patient had tests of cardiac enzymes which returned negative she was maintained on telemetry and she had ekg checked which did not reveal any changes this was patient who had dobutamine mibi which was negative for any evidence of ischemic changes during the mibi there was no evidence of ischemia and or scar the patient was continued on her outpatient medications including aspirin zocor and atenolol however at later point in her hospitalization she became hypotensive at which time her atenolol was temporarily dcd but this was restarted prior to discharge in terms of the patients cardiac function she has history of chf and is on lasix as an outpatient an echocardiogram was repeated during this hospitalization which was notable for an ef of trace to mild mr moderate tr and estimated pulmonary systolic pressure at mmhg the patient was continued on outpatient lasix regimen until at later point during this hospitalization the patient became hypertensive with acute renal failure at which time her lasix was discontinued lasix was restarted prior to discharge in terms of the patients rhythm she had no evidence of arrhythmias monitored throughout her hospitalization gi on the patient developed acute onset of diarrhea and lower abdominal pain now this pain was nonradiating alternating sharp and dull but constant associated with nausea and vomiting and frequent stools at times the stools were notable for bright red blood the patient was therefore started on levofloxacin and flagyl as treatment for diverticulitis versus ischemic colitis to further evaluate this ct scan of the abdomen was done which was notable for thickened colon for cm at the hepatic flexure given this information it was the gi consults opinion that this is most likely consistent with diverticulitis and the plan was to treat it aggressively with antibiotics and once the symptoms resolved recommended colonoscopy several weeks after discharge the patient was continued on levofloxacin and flagyl but then several days later became hypotensive with systolic blood pressures in the at this time the patients antibiotic coverage was changed to include ceptaz and vancomycin and she also received dose of gentamicin by the time of discharge the patients abdominal symptoms have completely resolved she is no longer having any abdominal pain and she needs no longer having any diarrhea and is tolerating regular diet without any difficulties the plan is for her to have followup colonoscopy as an outpatient pulmonary the patient was admitted for shortness of breath differential diagnosis at that time included chronic pulmonary embolism versus cardiac etiology versus deconditioning in the setting of chronic pulmonary fibrosis to establish that the patient did not have any pe she had lower extremity doppler exams which were negative she also had pt protocol ct which was negative for any evidence of clots because the patient does have cardiopulmonary hypertension she was started on coumadin as prophylaxis for any thrombosis in the setting of her low flow in her pulmonary vasculature throughout this hospitalization she was continued on her own home regimen of renal the patient has baseline chronic renal insufficiency with baseline creatinine at during this hospitalization at time that her diarrhea was very severe and when her blood pressures fell in the the patient developed acute renal failure with peak creatinine of with decreased urine output the thought of the team was that this represented renal failure in the setting of her diarrhea fluid losses and hypertension her pheno was consistent with this at she was treated with aggressive iv fluids she also had renal ultrasound which was normal she did have day of hematuria which was thought to be due most likely to foley trauma which resolved at the time of discharge id the patients hospital course was notable for diarrhea as mentioned in gi she was initially treated with levofloxacin and flagyl and then when she became hypertensive was then change her flagyl ceptaz and vancomycin with dose of gentamicin her symptoms dramatically improved on these antibiotics on she was changed from iv antibiotics to regimen of flagyl and levofloxacin the plan is for her to continue total of days of antibiotics anticipate the last day of antibiotic coverage will be rheumatology on the patient was noted to have left knee pain and was noted to have some focal lateral patellar tenderness and swelling knee aspirate was performed and urate crystals were identified and the patient was diagnosed with gout because of her chronic renal insufficiency and diarrhea the decision was made to treat her gout flare with steroids and she is currently is on steroid taper as treatment endocrine the patient has history of diabetes she takes insulin at home she was initially continued on an outpatient regimen however when she started to begin having massive diarrhea she was taken off her long acting insulin because she was not taking anything by at this time she was not tolerating regular diet and her insulin requirements were increasing it is recommended that as an outpatient she resumes one half of her regular outpatient insulin dose for or days to ensure that her insulin requirements in her diet are appropriate and then she should resume her regular insulin dosage discharge medications include aspirin mg atenolol mg lasix mg zoloft mg zocor mg neurontin mg levofloxacin mg coumadin mg prednisone taper which involves mg of prednisone on followed by mg of prednisone on and and then stop flagyl mg insulin units units once it is established that the patient has returned to her regular diet this dosage should be doubled to her outpatient regular dose and flexeril mg disposition the patient has been discharged to rehab facility followup the patient is to follow up with her primary care physician dr hargus following discharge additional instructions antibiotics should be continued until the patient should have her inr checked in days her goal inr is once off levofloxacin her dose of coumadin may need to be adjusted the patient should have an outpatient colonoscopy and treated for week to further assess for diverticulitis fingerstick blood glucoses should be followed regularly as the patients insulin dose is titrated up to her previous outpatient dose escription document kffocus dictated by okrent reed th am infected lt total hip replacement signed dis admission date report status signed discharge date attending kelley irwin service orthopedic service principal diagnosis infected left total hip replacement principal procedure removal of infected cemented left total hip replacement with debridement of the hip and placement of antibiotic impregnated cement spacers on history of present illness ms beish is year old female with multiple medical problems who initially sustained left hip intertrochanteric fracture in october of and underwent an orif with dhs on the screw ultimately cut off and she underwent removal of hardware on with insertion of hemiarthroplasty with antibiotic beads her culture grew coag negative staph at that time and she was treated with six weeks of iv antibiotics after multiple hip aspirations to confirm that the joint was no longer infected she underwent left total hip replacement on by dr sweis she ended up being hospitalized in gassonvenchand pendinea port from to with an coli bacteremia of unclear etiology although it was felt likely secondary to pyelonephritis during that hospitalization she developed neck pain and was found to have mrsa osteomyelitis at she underwent infusion on she ultimately completed weeks of iv vancomycin for her mrsa spinal infection and at the completion of the vancomycin therapy in february of was started on minocycline with plan for six month treatment she ultimately presented to dr amoako office on with increasing left groin hip lateral thigh pain over several months duration two left hip aspirates in august both grew mrsa and as such she was scheduled for an explant of her left total hip replacement with insertion of an antibiotic spacer on past medical history diabetes mellitus type ii myasthenia gravis hypertension steroid dependent asthma with multiple intubations as young adult depression gerd gi bleeds for which she was hospitalized in the dvt and pe in obstructive sleep apnea on home cpap osteoporosis peripheral neuropathy diverticulitis migraines obesity history of pneumonia history of septic right shoulder cervical discitis and vertebral osteomyelitis past surgical history left hip dhs removal of hardware left hip with insertion of hemiarthroplasty with antibiotic spacer on revision left total hip replacement on with cervical fusion arthroscopic right shoulder august of partial colectomy oophorectomy in february of cholecystectomy in early medications on admission oxycontin percocet two tabs neurontin mg fioricet one to two tabs fentanyl patch mcg multivitamin ativan mg ipratropium allergies imitrex causes vomiting vicodin causes vomiting iv contrast dye causes throat burning social history the patient is single and lives alone in utah she quit smoking tobacco years ago and does not drink alcohol physical examination on admission remarkable for an obese female ambulates with walker and an antalgic gait on the left she had mild tenderness with palpation in her mid cervical spine she had some mild distal left upper extremity and proximal left lower extremity weakness gentle range of motion of her left hip caused pain hospital course the patient was admitted on for initiation of iv antibiotic therapy at the request of the infectious disease service under the direction of dr willy kirkey prior to the initiation of antibiotic therapy she had blood cultures drawn which ultimately showed no growth given her neck pain and slight weakness she also had an mri of her cervical spine performed which showed no evidence of osteomyelitis preoperatively she was seen by both the infectious disease consult service as well as the medical consult service she was placed on low dose beta blocker at the recommendation of the medical consult service on the morning of hospital day the beta blocker was then discontinued under the recommendation of the medical consult service as it was felt to likely add little benefit she did receive one dose of coumadin the night before surgery in preparation for dvt prophylaxis she was ultimately taken to the operating room on hospital day where she underwent removal of her left total hip replacement with irrigation debridement and placement of an antibiotic spacer estimated blood loss was she received six units of packed red blood cells of crystalloid and of albumin intraoperatively gross pus was found intraoperative cultures were sent which ultimately grew mrsa the patient received perioperative stress dose hydrocortisone postoperatively she was taken to the surgical intensive care unit and intubated her postoperative hematocrit was the morning of postoperative day the patient remained intubated but was able to open her eyes and follow commands she was neurovascularly intact in the left lower extremity she was treated with lovenox only initially given that she did not initially have an ng tube so that medications including coumadin could be administered she was continued on the vancomycin the patient remained intubated throughout the remainder of postoperative day and into the morning of postoperative day her hematocrit had drifted down to on postoperative day for which she was transfused two units with her hematocrit up to she continued to remain hemodynamically stable and neurovascularly intact an ng tube had been placed on postoperative day so that medications including her mestinon could be given for her myasthenia gravis she was ultimately extubated mid morning on postoperative day her dressing was changed at that time and the incision was clean and intact without any erythema the patient remained in the surgical icu until postoperative day mainly with continued pain issues she had been on fentanyl drip and was transitioned over to dilaudid pca she was started on clear diet on postoperative day and transitioned over to regular insulin sliding scale from the insulin drip that she had been on to the early hours of postoperative day her hematocrit remained stable in the high her right ij central line was changed out over wire under sterile technique in the icu on postoperative day prior to transfer to the floor she was transferred to the floor in stable condition lat in the day on postoperative day she was taking at that time and her home medications were restarted including her home prednisone postoperative day pain continued to be her main issue and she was seen by the chronic pain service for recommendations on transitioning her off of the high dose dilaudid pca pca was discontinued and she was started on oxycodone in addition to her home fentanyl patch and oxycontin physical therapy worked with the patient throughout her hospital stay and were able to first sit her up on the edge of the bed on postoperative day she continued to remain afebrile hemodynamically stable and neurovascularly intact throughout the remainder of her hospitalization her hematocrit was stable in the high she had picc line placed on postoperative day for administration of her long term iv vancomycin the pain service continued to see the patient and titrate her pain medications with gradually improving effect the foley was discontinued the morning of postoperative day as the patient began to be able to move around little more easily by postoperative day she was more comfortable was tolerating regular diet and voiding shift without foley she was afebrile hemodynamically stable and neurovascularly intact she was continued on both coumadin and lovenox given that her inr was still not therapeutic she should continue on the coumadin with lovenox bridge until the inr is therapeutic the patient was cleared for transfer to rehab on postoperative day by the orthopedic infectious disease and physical therapy services
